title: 107_hr1509
content: The Act is titled the "National Media Campaign to Prevent Underage Drinking Act of 2001." It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a program for a national media campaign to prevent underage drinking. The Act titled "National Media Campaign to Prevent Underage Drinking Act of 2001" requires the Secretary to conduct a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the United States. The campaign is based on reputable scientific research and aims to supplement existing efforts by various entities. The Secretary is mandated to conduct a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the United States. The campaign aims to supplement existing efforts by various entities and coordinate with other Federal agencies. The Secretary is also required to target specific geographic areas with prevention or treatment resources in the media messages. The Secretary is mandated to conduct a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the United States. The campaign includes language-appropriate and culturally competent messages to reach minority groups. Funds are allocated for advertising, campaign development, media purchase, talent payments, and advertising production. The strategy planning document outlines the allocation of funds for various aspects of the advertising campaign, including media purchase, talent payments, advertising production costs, testing, and evaluation. Funds can also be used for partnerships with community groups and government organizations to support the campaign's effectiveness. Funds allocated for the advertising campaign can be used for partnerships with community, civic, and professional groups, government organizations, and entertainment industry collaborations to create underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats. Prohibitions include not supplanting community-based efforts or current pro bono public service time donated by broadcasting networks. Prohibitions for the advertising campaign funding include not supplanting community-based efforts, current pro bono public service time donated by broadcasting networks, partisan political purposes, featuring elected officials in media campaigns, or supporting advertising messages with company logos. Matching requirement is also a condition for each allocation. The Secretary must ensure that advertising messages funded for the national media campaign do not feature company logos. Sellers of media time or space must provide non-Federal contributions equal to 50% of the purchase price, which can be in the form of funds or public service announcements. The Secretary is required to develop and submit a comprehensive strategy to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Secretary must develop and submit a comprehensive strategy to Congress that includes the nature of underage drinking, scientific basis, target audiences, campaign goals, message points, implementation plan, evaluation plan, and estimated costs. Annual reports on campaign activities and progress reports are also required. The Secretary must submit a progress report to Congress on the national media campaign's performance goals based on measurable outcomes. Funding for this campaign is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2007, with a limitation of $1,000,000 for specific activities.
